summary: This document is an email chain between Assistant U.S. Attorneys from the Southern District of New York and Gary Bloxsome, a UK solicitor representing the Duke of York (Prince Andrew). The correspondence details negotiations over the Duke's potential cooperation with the U.S. investigation into Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein, with the U.S. side seeking a voluntary interview and the Duke's legal team offering only a written witness statement limited to the 1994-1997 indictment period. The U.S. ultimately states it will proceed with a compelled interview request via the UK Central Authority.

persons.name: Gary Bloxsome
persons.role: Partner at Blackfords LLP, Solicitor for the Duke of York
persons.context: The primary UK solicitor representing the Duke of York, negotiating the terms of his client's potential cooperation with the U.S. investigation into Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Daniel Cundy
persons.context: A UK solicitor at Blackfords LLP who is copied on the correspondence and provides legal references regarding compelled interviews and use protections.

persons.name: Jennifer Richardson
persons.context: An Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York who is part of the team communicating with the Duke of York's UK legal representatives.

persons.name: The Duke of York
persons.context: Prince Andrew, the client of Gary Bloxsome. The U.S. investigation seeks his interview regarding his association with Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein, but his legal team offers only a limited written statement.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of a pending U.S. criminal indictment (1994-1997). The U.S. investigation seeks information from the Duke of York about her and Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named alongside Ghislaine Maxwell as someone the Duke of York had an association with, and about whom the U.S. investigation is seeking information.

connections.description: Gary Bloxsome is the solicitor representing the Duke of York in negotiations with U.S. prosecutors regarding his cooperation with the investigation.
The Duke of York is acknowledged by his own lawyer as having an 'association' with Ghislaine Maxwell, which is relevant to the U.S. investigation.
The Duke of York is acknowledged by his own lawyer as having an 'association' with Jeffrey Epstein.
Both are partners at Blackfords LLP and are working together on the legal representation of the Duke of York.
They are opposing parties in a negotiation, with Richardson representing the U.S. prosecution seeking an interview and Bloxsome representing the witness/subject resisting a full interview.

events.title: U.S. Declines Written Statement, Will Seek Compelled Interview
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's office informs Gary Bloxsome that because his client declined a voluntary interview, they will proceed with an MLA (Mutual Legal Assistance) request to the UKCA for a compelled interview.

keyFacts: Prince Andrew (the Duke of York), through his lawyers, declined to sit for a voluntary interview with U.S. prosecutors investigating Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein.
Prince Andrew's legal team offered only to provide a written witness statement and answer written questions, but sought to limit the scope to the 1994-1997 period of the Maxwell indictment.
U.S. prosecutors explicitly stated they regarded Prince Andrew not as a witness but as a 'subject' of their investigation.

The U.S. side rejected the offer of a written statement as insufficient and announced their intent to formally seek a compelled interview of Prince Andrew through the UK Central Authority (UKCA) via an MLA request.
The email chain reveals extensive negotiations over several months (July-August 2020) between U.S. prosecutors and Prince Andrew's UK solicitors, Blackfords LLP.
